That tutorial is an old one about a FAT16 system, you used FAT32 and BECAUSE of this you got:  

> Then there is written Operating System not found.  
> I have included like in the introduction DSL and PuppyLinux but it is still not working I don't understand...

Let's try making it boot.  

Try using fuwi's batch.  

If you had taken the time to read the given links, you would have found how booting from FAT32 is sometimes problematic when using the 2K/XP/2003 bootsector, and how the procedure by fuwi was devised to work around the problem.  

If it works we'll talk about multibooting.  

For the record, the original guide by **diddy** is actually TWO guides, one using syslinux and one using grub4dos, once you run succesfully fuwi's batch, you are in a situation similar to that in step 5, but with the grldr.mbr installed, useful to workaround the said bootsector problem by bypassing it and loading directly the OS kernel files.  

In other words, you should be in a situation with the grldr.mbr properly installed as in here:  
[http://diddy.boot-la...ll.htm#method08](http://diddy.boot-land.net/grub4dos/files/install.htm#method08 "External link")  
INSTEAD of being in the one here:  
[http://diddy.boot-la...ll.htm#method05](http://diddy.boot-land.net/grub4dos/files/install.htm#method05 "External link")  

Guess who, roughly 1 year and a half later, wrote the current grub4dos guide?:  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=5187](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=5187 "External link")  

![:good:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/good.gif)  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: wimb
forumNotes.content:
You need in menu.lst a forward slash instead of the backslash. For me is working: ``` title 07 - Puppy Linux - NTFS Read / Write find --set-root /grldr kernel /vmlinuz root=/dev/ram0 initrd=initrd.gz PMEDIA=usbflash PKEYS=uk initrd /initrd.gz title 10 - Damn Small Linux - NTFS Read Only - Knoppix find --set-root /grldr kernel /linux24 ramdisk_size=100000 init=/etc/init lang=us apm=power-off vga=791 initrd=minirt24.gz nomce noapic qemu quiet BOOT_IMAGE=knoppix frugal initrd /minirt24.gz ```
Each entry consists of 4 rules. The kernel rule can be very long and can appear as two rules, but it is 1 rule EDIT: Puppy Linux contains GParted

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> I have 2GB RAM, can I now use .iso with memory mappint until 2GB?

If whatever you boot needs 0 bytes of RAM to run, yes.  

Otherwise, you will need to subtract at least the minimum requirement for the particular OS you need to boot.  

Of course it is plain counterproductive to limit RAM to the OS in order to load a larger image to RAM, and I doubt ![:good:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/good.gif) it will be faster when loading, though it may be faster when running ![^_^](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy.png).  

jaclaz

> I have 2GB RAM, can I now use .iso with memory mappint until 2GB?

If whatever you boot needs 0 bytes of RAM to run, yes.  

Otherwise, you will need to subtract at least the minimum requirement for the particular OS you need to boot.  

Of course it is plain counterproductive to limit RAM to the OS in order to load a larger image to RAM, and I doubt ![:good:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/good.gif) it will be faster when loading, though it may be faster when running ![^_^](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy.png).

forumNotes.author: Icecube
forumNotes.content:
>
> > ``` > title PMAGIC Default settings (Runs from RAM) > > root (hd0,0) > > find --set-root /grldr > > kernel /pmagic/bzImage root=/dev/ram0 initrd=/pmagic/initrd PMEDIA=usbflash > > initrd /pmagic/initrd > ``` > >
> This isn't the default Parted Magic setting. The PMEDIA parameter isn't used in Parted Magic (Puppy linux uses it). Look in the menu.lst or grub4dos.lst file in the iso of the Parted Magic version that you use, for the correct parameters. Also for the other entries: **initrd=** on the kernel line doesn't make any sense. I severely doubt that the PMEDIA parameter makes any sense for OpenSUSE and Backtrack. You can't just assume that because Puppy Linux uses the PMEDIA option, that other distributions use it too and that it will magically solve all your problems. **Always start from the isolinux.cfg file to make your grub4dos menu entries:** * Copy the kernel line (if it starts with 'KERNEL', convert to lowercase 'kernel') * add everything on the 'APPEND' line in the isolinux.cfg to the kernel' line in the grub4dos config file, **except** for the **initrd=blablabla** part * add a new line to your grub4dos config file to which you copy the **initrd=blablabla** line of the isolinux.cfg file and replace the '=' with a ' '.
The isolinux.cfg entry for Parted Magic 3.7: ``` KERNEL /pmagic/bzImage APPEND noapic initrd=/pmagic/initrd root=/dev/ram0 init=/linuxrc vga=791 sleep=0 ramdisk_size=25000 loglevel=0 keymap=us ``` becomes this, in grub4dos style: ``` kernel /pmagic/bzImage noapic root=/dev/ram0 init=/linuxrc vga=791 sleep=0 ramdisk_size=25000 loglevel=0 keymap=us initrd /pmagic/initrd ```
The Parted Magic entry is not complete, but it can be that it boots (parameters depend on the version). I also don't know if the Backtrack entry has all parameters. **A cleaned up config file:** ``` timeout=5 title BT4 Beta – Console root (hd0,0) find --set-root /grldr kernel /BT4boot/backtrackkernelvmlinuz root=/dev/ram0 initrd /BT4boot/initrd1.gz title PMAGIC Default settings (Runs from RAM) root (hd0,0) find --set-root /grldr kernel /pmagic/bzImage root=/dev/ram0 initrd /pmagic/initrd title Boot VISTAPEv12b3 - ISO from HD into RAMDISK find --set-root --ignore-floppies /VistaPE.iso map --mem /VISTAPE.iso (hd32) map --hook root (hd32) chainloader /BOOTMGR title Opensuse 11.1 GNOME Live CD find --set-root /grldr kernel /boot/i386/loader/linux ramdisk_size=512000 ramdisk_blocksize=4096 splash=silent showopts initrd /boot/i386/loader/initrd title Opensuse 11.1 NetInstall map /OPENSUSENETINSTALL.iso (hd32) map --hook root (hd32) chainloader (hd32) ```

forumNotes.author: Icecube
forumNotes.content:
Converting isolinux syntax to grub4dos synthax is always possible for linux based disks, which have a isolinux.cfg with something similar to: ``` KERNEL /some/kernel APPEND initrd=/some/initrd parameter1 parameter2 ```
If an entry in the isolinux.cfg file boots a .c32 file, the conversion to grub4dos syntax depends on how it is implemented in grub4dos. You can download UBCD50b12 for examples, if you want.
